texts.shortText: Large, fairly stout cormorant, entirely black apart from white rump during breeding season. Head with a small peaked crest. Bill and surrounding skin entirely black (distinguishing it from Cape and Crowned cormorants). Eyes divided horizontally – top half orange, bottom half green with narrow orange border. Legs and feet black.
Total length 75 cm, wingspan 130 cm, mass about 1800 g, sexes alike.

Global: Endemic to southern Africa

Local/Regional: West coast species, found from northern Namibia to Cape Agulhas.

Uncommon species, with a restricted range more or less corresponding to that of kelp forests.  Total population probably only about 3000 pairs and has declined by more than 50% in recent decades, probably due to decreasing food supplies and displacement from some colonies by expanding seal populations.

Found in small colonies mostly on islands, and seldom ranges inland, or more than 10 km from breeding sites. Often seen mixed with other cormorants. Flight rather heavy and laboured, usually low over water. Forages close inshore, but can dive to at least 28 m, deeper dives initiated by jumping out of water. Dives each about 30-60 secs and occur in bouts of about one hour, with rests between. Sometimes spread wings after foraging to warm body and aid digestion.

Feeds mainly on a variety of small benthic fish including klipfish, gobies, sucker fish and blennies, but also range of invertebrates, mainly rock lobster, rock crabs and mantis shrimp, but also cephalopods, abalone, etc.

Usually nests in small colonies of 20-100 pairs on islands or large rocks, cliffs, breakwaters etc. adjacent to the sea. Nest a large mound made almost entirely of seaweeds and cemented together with guano. Eggs 1-3 pale bluish-white with chalky outer layer. Breed year round in the Western Cape, but mainly May-October. Incubation period 28-32 days, fledge after 55-70 days but cared for by parents to 3 months.

Could be confused with Cape or Bank cormorants, but those are smaller and both have orange colouring around gape of bill. Crowned cormorant also has red eye and longer tail and Cape cormorant blue eye and no crest.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 354).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 577).
